title: 30-year-old Soviet TV adaptation of The Lord of the Rings surfaces on YouTube

last_post.content:
An Andrei Tarkovsky masterwork it is not. But the nostalgia is strong with this Soviet-era adaptation of Tolkien's masterwork, thanks to its alien visual language and apparent C movie budget. If you're a creator, player, archivist or fan of #interactivefiction we welcome you to join the discussion at intfiction.org!

https://intfiction.org

#if #textadventures #inform7 #twine #parser #CYOA #xyzzy #adventuregame #infocom #zork

If you’re a fan of literary #indiegames and have never heard of “The Gostak,” one of the wildest experiments to come out of the 90s/00s era #InteractiveFiction renaissance, you’ll want to read this article. There’s never been another game like it before or since. https://if50.substack.com/p/the-gostak #gamestudies #50YearsOfTextGames

I (shamefully) keep tabs where "According to Cain" stands on various IFDB charts.

Right now it's #3 on the top TADS game list, right behind Ian Finley's classic "Babel."

This is significant for me because playing "Babel" 20+ years ago first planted the idea in my head that I could write an IF of my own.

Stick to your vision.

https://ifdb.org/search?searchfor=system:TADS

#InteractiveFiction #VideoGames #Persistence

title: What's Up With That: Building Bigger Roads Actually Makes Traffic Worse

last_post.content: "The concept is called induced demand, which is economist-speak for when increasing the supply of something (like roads) makes people want that thing even more. Though some traffic engineers made note of this phenomenon at least as early as the 1960s, it is only in recent years that social scientists have collected enough data to show how this happens pretty much every time we build new roads." https://www.wired.com/2014/06/wuwt-traffic-induced-demand/

Judith Love Cohen was the engineer who made Apollo's Abort Guidance System, which was crucial to saving the ill-fated Apollo 13. She finished it while in labor, then (the same day) delivered her younger son -- the actor Jack Black.

This is one of those utterly remarkable #space stories that I stumble over once in a while and it blows my mind afresh every single time.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judith_Love_Cohen

title: Linux Foundation is Eating the World

last_post.content:
#OpenStreetMap

Unpicking the Matryoshka of Linux Foundation shell companies is quite interesting.

The “Overture Maps Foundation” is a Joint Development Foundation Projects, LLC “series” and the JDFP LLC is a subsidiary of the Joint Development Foundation.

https://www.jolts.world/index.php/jolts/article/view/137/262 has some information on how this is supposed to work.

In summary: the OMF is a subsidiary of the JDFP LLC that is a subsidiary of the JDF and that in turn is operated and controlled by the LF.

Blog post: "Deploying key transparency at WhatsApp"

Key transparency has been a sort of holy grail of encrypted messaging systems which ensures that if the messaging system advertises a malicious public key for your user, there's a permanent record of it.

There have been several projects before this like CONIKS and Google's Key Transparency, but none of them shipped. Seeing it actually happen is exciting for me.

https://engineering.fb.com/2023/04/13/security/whatsapp-key-transparency/

title: Minutes to Midnight - A personal manifesto

last_post.content:
This might be the most important blog post I ever wrote. It's been a while since I wanted to publish some sort of personal manifesto on my site.

After I stopped promoting myself as if I were a brand, I needed to put my foot down and declare what I stand for, on the only place that's not going away: my personal website.

So, here it is. A personal manifesto, where I touch on these topics:

#MentalHealth
#Sustainability
#Technology
#SmallWeb
#IndieWeb
#SocialMedia

I need privacy. Not because my actions are questionable, but because 'your' judgement and intentions are.
​
And it doesn't matter whether or not my communications are weighty or frivolous in nature - they are mine and only for those whom I've chosen to share them with. Not the government's, nor goog's, nor my ISP's, but mine.
​
Also, what is legal where I live today, may not be legal tomorrow and my discussion of it may incriminate my future self. It has happened in the past many times to others in other places.

Question for he #LIS #library folks on here: I'm looking for a simple way to embed #bibliographic #metadata into an #HTML page for consumption by tools like #Zotero. #CoinS / #OpenURL / #Z39_88 seems to be an option and it does work. But there appears to be no field for the #editor(s) of a #book and I'm having troubles with the #DOI. Documentation seems hard to find -- this seemed useful, but limited: https://web.archive.org/web/20140922055507/http://ocoins.info/cobgbook.html. – Where should I look? title: Proton Pass is now in beta | Proton

last_post.content:
Hey @sc00bz, Proton is launching their own password manager. Release version will be opensource etc.

They will encrypt all data using AES-256-GCM, use a strong bcrypt implementation, a hardened SRP for authentication, and provide a fully integrated 2FA feature with 2FA autofill.

No info though about any family/group/enterprise management capabilities though, which introduces tons more issues to handle.

More info:
https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-beta

Security model:
https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-security-model

Hey @sc00bz, Proton is launching their own password manager. Release version will be opensource etc.

They will encrypt all data using AES-256-GCM, use a strong bcrypt implementation, a hardened SRP for authentication, and provide a fully integrated 2FA feature with 2FA autofill.

No info though about any family/group/enterprise management capabilities though, which introduces tons more issues to handle.

More info:
https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-beta

Security model:
https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-security-model

Today I publish a rather simple #Space #Science with #Python video on "Sample Weights".

Our Cassini CDA Calibration fit from last time did not consider the input data distribution. In fact, mostly people don't do that when conducting regression tasks. But ... well ... you should (either by over- / under-sampling, or sample weights).

Our case is too simple for that (in fact). But it is best practice nonetheless #ml #ai #keras #coding #programming

https://youtu.be/x6kDzp1thHo

title: Evaluating Verifiability in Generative Search Engines

last_post.content:
Responses from existing generative search engines (Bing Chat, NeevaAI, this http URL, and YouChat) are fluent and appear informative, but frequently contain unsupported statements and inaccurate citations: 51% of generated sentences are fully supported by citations and only 74% of citations support their associated sentence
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

Today's the 100th birthday of a unique writer, Avram Davidson.

You may not be familiar with his work, but the ebook of The Avram Davidson Treasury is free today, and it includes many of his best stories introduced or afterworded by such folks as Guy Davenport, Ursula Le Guin, William Gibson, Harlan Ellison, and Ray Bradbury — a perfect way to get familiar! https://myemail.constantcontact.com/Avram-Davidson-s-100th-Birthday.html?soid=1102478586450&aid=jg-YBPJ2hwk

Annie Easley, born #OTD in 1933, began her career at the NACA as a “human computer,” performing complex calculations. When machines began to replace human computers, Easley adapted, becoming an expert computer programmer.

title: Patricia Lockwood · Diary: Saving a Life · LRB 16 February 2023

last_post.content: “‘Oh my God, I’m afraid of heights,’ I said, at the exact moment he gasped: ‘I think I’m scared of the Ferris wheel?’ Each revolution seemed like a year. ‘It lasts this long?’ we kept saying, clutching each other. ‘It’s going around again?’ But babies are on it – like life. ‘It must be safe.’” https://www.lrb.co.uk/the-paper/v45/n04/patricia-lockwood/diary via @agentdana

24.4., 17:15 Uhr
Sarah Lang @sarahalang:
Mehr als nur Lückenfüller. Das Gender Data Gap als dringendes Thema für historische Disziplinen und Digital Humanities
https://events.gwdg.de/event/449/
by: @msiemund @InFoDiTex #KevinWunsch
see you

hab mich gerade angemeldet

Many apps are inaccessible for blind/VI people. Developers usually have to implement #Accessibility features from scratch for each platform they develop on, which can scare them away. The good folks over @accesskit are trying to change that with their #Foss project, #AccessKit. Their goal is to create a cross-platform solution for accessibility that only has to be implemented once. I'm posting this to spread the word. Let's help them reach their goals! https://accesskit.dev/ #Blind #A11Y

Our #chi2023 paper considers how people who stutter access voice assistants — and, it does a rare thing!, it starts with a large-scale study with people who stutter (n=61), connects those results to a deep understanding of how speech systems work, and follows through with technical improvements that significantly improve performance (in several ways, including in the released “Siri Pause Time”) feature … this is the kind of work I came to industry to be part of.

https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~jbigham/pubs/pdfs/2023/stutter-speech.pdf

title: POGO Calls for DOJ to Investigate Clarence Thomas, Seek Civil Penalties

last_post.content: Last week, my @pogowatchdog colleague Sarah Turberville and I filed a complaint with DOJ’s Civil Division urging it to seek civil monetary penalties against Clarence Thomas — as that office has done with other officials who violated the disclosure law. The burden of proof is much lower than in a criminal case, requiring a showing only that it’s more likely than not that he violated the law knowingly and willfully. The fine is $71,316 per omission. https://www.pogo.org/letter/2023/04/pogo-calls-for-doj-to-investigate-clarence-thomas-seek-civil-penalties

Yes. SpaceX has done bad things and deserves to be criticized for them. But (and I think this is analogous to a lot of issues) the problem here isn’t that SpaceX isn’t NASA; it’s that NASA doesn’t have the political room to experiment and inevitably sometimes fail that SpaceX does. This is too complex an issue to fit all the layers and nuance into one honk, but “SpaceX is bad because their rockets explode” is not a good analysis. https://chaos.social/@russss/110249195107310284

title: 'On Savage Shores' Review: Can White Academics Write Native History?

last_post.content:
New from me, for Foreign Policy magazine: a British historian has written a book searching for Native stories amidst scraps of colonizers' paper records from the age of tall ships.

But is she telling white stories or #Indigenous ones?
